The Story of the Golden Cat (103) The Story of the Golden Cat: In the past, King Evil Birth went on a tour of the forest garden. In the hall of the garden, he saw a golden cat enter from the northeast corner to the southwest corner.
The king immediately sent someone to search and dig it up. He found a copper urn, the urn could hold three bushels, and it was full of golden coins.
Gradually digging deeper, he found another jar, and in this way, he obtained three layers of jars, each holding three bushels.

The king then asked:

At that time there was a poor man who had just obtained three coins from selling firewood. Having heard these words, he gave rise to a joyful mind and immediately placed the coins in the bowl, sincerely making a vow.

Five li away from his home, on his way back, he was joyful with every step. When he reached his gate, he made a sincere vow towards the place where he had been soliciting donations, and then entered his home.
The Venerable One said:

Because of the causes and conditions of offering three coins in the past, he was respected in life after life, and always obtained such a triple coin jar. Because of the joy step by step within five li, he always had this gold coin within five li.
The king heard the past causes and conditions, and left with joy.

The cause of seeking the god Vima for the hope of great wealth: In the past, there were two brothers whose family was poor. The elder brother always diligently worshipped day and night, seeking the god Vima, hoping to become greatly wealthy, while sending his younger brother to plow the fields and plant crops.
In this way, he sought for many years.
At that time, the god Vima transformed into the younger brother and went to the elder brother's side.
The elder brother scolded his younger brother, saying:
Why don't you plow and plant?
What are you coming here for?
At that time, the younger brother replied:
Elder brother, in the heavenly temple, day and night you pray, hoping to become greatly wealthy;
Today, I also wish to emulate my elder brother, to observe the precepts and make wishes, hoping to obtain great wealth.
His elder brother said to his younger brother:
You do not plow the fields or plant seeds, how can you obtain abundant wealth and grain?
The younger brother replied to his elder brother:
Is it really because of planting that one reaps the harvest?
The elder brother was unable to respond.
Then the god Vima restored his heavenly form and said to him:
Now my power can only assist you, and if you practice giving today, then you can become wealthy.
But because you did not practice giving in the past, you are now poor.
Even if you diligently seek wealth and treasures from me day and night, what can you obtain?
It is like the amra tree, even if you serve hundreds of thousands of heavenly spirits in winter, you cannot obtain its fruits.
You are also like this. If you do not cultivate causes beforehand, you will not be able to seek great wealth from me.
When the fruit is ripe, it is obtained by itself without seeking.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
Meritorious karma is like a ripe fruit, not obtained through sacrifice.
People ride the cart of precepts and later attain heaven.
Concentration and wisdom are like a lamp going out, attaining the unconditioned.
All are obtained through practice. What is the use of seeking heaven?

(108) The Conditions of Worshipping the Tree Deity In the past, there was an old man whose family was extremely wealthy. This old man, thinking of obtaining meat, deceitfully made a pretext, pointing to a tree at the edge of the field, and said to his sons:
Now, the reason why our family business has become prosperous is due to the grace and blessings of the tree deity. Today, you all!
You should select a sheep from the flock to use as a sacrifice.
At that time, the sons, following their father's instructions, immediately killed a sheep and made offerings to the tree, and then built a shrine to the deity at the foot of the tree.
Later, when the father's life ended and his lifespan was exhausted, he was pursued by his past actions and was reborn in the flock of sheep in his own home.

At that time, when the sons were about to make offerings to the tree deity, they took a sheep and happened to obtain their father. They were about to kill him, but the sheep bleated and laughed, saying:
What kind of spiritual being is there in this tree?
In the past, for the sake of thinking about meat, I falsely made you sacrifice, and we all ate this meat together.
Now, repaying the calamity and sin, I alone will bear it first.

At that time, there was an arhat who came to beg for food. He saw that his deceased father had received the body of a sheep. He then borrowed the host's eye of the Way, allowing him to observe himself. He then knew that it was his father. He was heartbroken. He immediately destroyed the tree spirit, repented and cultivated blessings, and no longer killed living beings.

The Conditions of a Woman Disgusted with Desire and Leaving the Home (109) The Conditions of a Woman Disgusted with Desire and Leaving the Home: In the past, there was a woman who was upright and extremely beautiful. She left the home to cultivate the Way in the Dharma of non-Buddhists.
At that time, people asked:
With such a countenance, you should be in the secular world. Why did you leave the home?
The woman replied:
As for me today, it is not that I am not upright, but I have been disgusted with sexual desire since I was young. Now, I therefore leave the home.

When I was at home, because of my beauty, I was given in marriage early, and I gave birth to a son early. The child grew up and became incomparably handsome, but I felt him becoming emaciated, as if he were sick.
I asked the child about the cause of his illness, but he refused to speak. When I kept asking, he had no choice but to tell his mother, saying:
'If I don't tell you, I'm afraid my life won't be spared;
if I want to tell you, it's too shameful.'
He then told his mother:
'I want to have you for my sexual desires, but because I can't, that's why I'm sick.'
His mother immediately said:
'Since ancient times, how could there be such a thing?'
She then thought to herself:
'If I don't comply, the child may die. Now I'd rather go against reason to save my child's life.'
She then called the child and wanted to follow his wishes.
As I was about to put my child on the bed, the ground suddenly split open, and my child immediately sank into the earth alive. I was shocked and grabbed my child's hair with my hand.
But my child's hair is still in my arms today.
I am deeply moved by this event, and therefore I have left home.

King Nanda wanted to invite him into the palace. He immediately had a small house built, making the door extremely low, hoping to make NÄgasena bend his body in submission. However, NÄgasena knew that he wanted to harm him, so he refused to enter and did not submit to his humiliation.
At that time, King Nanda prepared food and drink for him, giving him coarse food and several kinds of food. After eating three or five spoonfuls, he said he was full.
Later, he was given fine and delicious food, and then he ate again. The king asked again:

Sthira
answered, I was satisfied with coarse food, but not with fine food.
He then said to the king, On the palace roof now, gather people to fill it.

Sthira then said to the king, Coarse food is like the people, fine food is like the king. Who would not make way when seeing the king?
The king asked again, Between those who have left home and those who have not, who attains the Way?
Sthira answered, Both can attain the Way.
The king asked again, If both can attain the Way, why leave home?

It is like being three thousand li away from here. If you send a young and strong person to ride a horse, carry provisions, and take weapons, can they arrive quickly?
The king replied:

Sena said again:
If you send an old person to ride a skinny horse, and they have no provisions, can they arrive?
The king said:
Even if they carry provisions, I'm afraid they won't be able to reach their destination, let alone without provisions.
Sena said:
Leaving the household to attain the Way is like the young and strong, while staying in the household to attain the Way is like the old man.
The king asked again:
Now I want to ask about matters concerning the body. Am I permanent or impermanent? Answer according to my intention.

Then the king asked again:

Sena replied:
It is like a woman who eats cakes, meat, and vegetables. All the food and drink are digested.
When she becomes pregnant, the kalala stage is like a tiny particle. How does it grow so big without being digested?
The king said:

Sena replied:
In those hells, it is also the power of karma that keeps the life force alive.

The Story of an Unfilial Wife Who Wanted to Harm Her Mother-in-law but Instead Killed Her Husband (112) The Story of an Unfilial Wife Who Wanted to Harm Her Mother-in-law but Instead Killed Her Husband: In the past, there was a wife who was stubborn and disobedient, and everything she did was contrary to her mother-in-law. When scolded by her mother-in-law, she always held grudges.
Her hateful thoughts grew stronger, and she planned to kill her mother-in-law. Later, she devised a scheme and told her husband to kill his own mother.
The husband was foolish and immediately followed his wife's words. He took his mother to the wilderness, bound her hands and feet, and was about to harm her.
The extreme wickedness moved the heavens above. Clouds and fog gathered in the four directions, and lightning struck, killing his son.
The mother then returned home. Her daughter-in-law opened the door and thought it was her husband. She asked:
Have you killed her?
The mother-in-law replied:
I have killed her.
By the next day, they realized the husband was dead.
The crime of unfiliality resulted in such immediate retribution. Later, he entered hell and suffered immeasurable pain.

The King of Varanasi hears the story of the call from the charnel ground (113) The King of Varanasi hears the story of the call from the charnel ground. All dharmas, if they can be obtained through seeking, can be obtained through skillful means;
if they cannot be sought, even if one tries to forcefully obtain them, they cannot be obtained at all.
It is like squeezing sand to get oil or churning ice to get butter - it is impossible, and only brings on one's own exhaustion.
In the past, in the country of Varanasi, there was a king named Brahma-renowned. He always heard a voice calling out from the charnel ground in the middle of the night, saying:
Hey, King! Hey, King!
In this way, he heard the voice three times in one night.
The king heard the strange voice and was greatly startled. The sound continued without interruption for a long time.
The king gathered the Brahmins, astrologers, and fortune-tellers, and discussed with them, saying:
I always hear a voice from the charnel ground calling out to me at night. I am always afraid and dare not respond.
The people replied:
In that charnel ground, there must be a strange creature making this sound. Now, we should send a brave and courageous messenger to the charnel ground to investigate.
The king then issued a proclamation:
If there is anyone who can go to the charnel ground at night, I will reward them with five hundred gold coins.
At that time, there was a man who was orphaned and had no father. His family was very poor, but he had great courage. He immediately volunteered.
He put on armor, took a sword and staff in his hand, and went to the cemetery at night, hearing the king's voice calling out. He then shouted:ğŸ”½Hey!
Who are you?
He replied:
I am the hidden treasure of the conch shell.
He said to the volunteer:
You are a strong man. I always call out to that king at night. If that king were to respond to me, I want to go to his treasury.
But that king is timid and has never responded to me. Now, I have seven followers. Tomorrow morning, I will go to your house.
The volunteer asked:
When you come tomorrow, what should I use to welcome you?
The conch shell replied:

You just need to sweep the house, remove the filth, decorate with fragrant flowers, make it extremely clean, and prepare eight containers each of grape juice, ghee, and milk porridge. When eight monks arrive, use a stick to hit the head of the senior monk and say 'enter the corner.' In this way, drive them all into the corner in order.
After the person received the notice, they immediately returned home.
They borrowed five hundred gold coins from the king to use for the offerings.
The king asked them,
What is that sound?
The person who received the notice deceitfully replied that it was a ghost.
The person who received the notice heard what Conch Ear said and privately rejoiced. They invited a barber to adorn themselves.
By the next day, the offerings were prepared. Eight monks came to receive the food.

After the meal was finished, he hit the head of the upper seat and drove him into the corner. He immediately turned into a bag of gold coins. He drove in the others in order, and they turned into eight bags of gold.
At that time, the barber was in the door hole, and seeing him obtain the treasure, he silently thought to himself:
I understand this method. Let me try to imitate it.

Later, he prepared as before, invited the eight practitioners, set up the meal, and after it was finished, closed the door, blocked the door, hit the head of the upper seat, hoping for the same as before to obtain a heap of precious treasures.
However, the head of this practitioner broke open, blood flowed, and it stained the bed and seat. He was driven into the corner, and in his urgency, he lost his feces.

In order, the other seven people were all beaten, rolling on the ground. In the middle, there was one person with great strength. He immediately pulled his hand out and rushed outside, raising his voice and shouting:
The host here wants to harm us.
At that time, the king of that country sent someone to investigate. He immediately arrested the host and questioned him about the situation in detail.
At that time, the barber explained the matter in detail to the king.

The king then sent someone to the house of the bounty hunter to examine his gold and treasures, intending to tax and confiscate them, but they turned into poisonous snakes and transformed into a mass of fire.
The king then said:
This is your blessing.

The foolish in the world are also like this. They possess diligence, uphold the eight precepts, obtain good karmic rewards, gradually practice the eightfold right path, and attain the fruit of no outflows.

They then want to imitate others, uphold the eight precepts, have no sincerity within, and seek benefits and happiness. Since they have no good fruits, they instead obtain misfortune, just like that foolish person, no different.

114. The Causes of an Old Bhiká¹£u Attaining the Four Fruits (114) The Buddha's teachings are vast and boundless in their salvation. Those who sincerely seek the Way will all attain its fruits. Even if one jokes, one's blessings will not be wasted.

In the past, there was an old bhiká¹£u who was already decrepit and confused. Seeing the various teachings expounded by the young bhiká¹£us, he heard them speak of the four fruits and gave rise to admiration. He said to the young bhiká¹£us:
You are wise and intelligent. I wish to exchange the four fruits with you.
The young bhiká¹£us scoffed and said:
We have the four fruits. We need good food before we can give them to you.

When the old bhiká¹£u heard these words, he was overjoyed. He immediately untied his robe and used it to buy what was needed. He then prepared various delicacies and invited the young bhiká¹£us, asking for the four fruits.
The younger monks, after eating, pointed at the elder monks and said,
Venerable Sirs!
Sit in a corner of this house, and we will give you the fruit.
When the elder monks heard this, they were delighted and sat as instructed.
The younger monks then hit their heads with a leather ball and said to them,

When the elder monks heard this, they focused their attention without distraction and attained the first fruit.
The younger monks teased them again, saying,
Although you have now attained the fruit of stream-entry, you still have seven more births and deaths. Move to another corner, and we will give you the fruit of once-returning.
Because the elder monks had attained the first fruit, their minds became even more advanced, and they moved to sit elsewhere.
The younger monks again hit their heads with a ball and said to them,
We will give you the second fruit.
At that time, the old monk became even more focused and attained the second fruit.
The young monks teased him again, saying:

You have now attained the fruit of once-returning, but you still have the difficulty of coming and going in birth and death. You should move your seat again, and we will give you the fruit of non-returning.
At that time, the old monk moved his seat as he was told, and the young monks again hit him with the ball and said:
We will now give you the third fruit.
At that time, the old monk was delighted to hear this and redoubled his sincere mind, and immediately he attained the fruit of non-returning.
The young monks teased him again, saying:

You have now attained the fruit of non-returning, but you still have a body with outflows in the form and formless realms, which is impermanent and subject to change, and every moment is suffering. You should move your seat again, and we will next give you the fruit of arhatship.
At that time, the old monk moved his seat as instructed. The young monks again kicked his head with their leather balls and said to him:
We now give you that fourth fruit.
At that time, the old monk single-mindedly contemplated and immediately attained arhatship.

Having attained the four fruits, he was overjoyed. He prepared various delicacies and fragrant flowers to invite the young monks to repay their kindness and virtues. He discussed the undefiled merits of the path with the young monks.
The young monks' words were stuck.
At that time, the old monk said to them:
I have already attained the fruit of arhatship.
When the young monks heard these words, they all repented of their previous jesting offenses.
Therefore, practitioners should always remember goodness. Even if they jest, they will still receive real rewards, let alone if they do it with utmost sincerity.

115. The Causes of a Woman Sincerely Attaining the Fruit of the Path (115) The causes of a woman sincerely attaining the fruit of the path. If a person seeks the path, it is essential to be sincere. When sincerity moves the mind, one can attain the fruit of the path.

However, this woman deeply contemplated conditioned phenomena, which are impermanent, suffering, empty, and not self-controlled. Deeply observing with her mind, she immediately attained the first fruit.
